results.title: Germaine Greer's Sydney
results.creator_credit: John McGreevy, Pat Ferns, Nielsen-Ferns International and John McGreevy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cities”.
A look at Sydney with Germaine Greer. She comments on it being a city “where the poorest people can be millionaires. Where, for practically nothing, you can do the same things that in other countries you have to join select clubs to do.”

results.title: Sugata Sanshiro = Judo Saga
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Keiji Matsuzaki and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description:
In the late 19th century, Sanshiro becomes the master of the new fighting style of judo, gradually proving its superiority over the more established martial art of jujitsu, and learns to gain spiritual peace at the same time. Sanshiro, a strong and stubborn youth, is determined to conquer the discipline that has impressed him so, but must suppress his impulsive will and learn “satori,” the calm acceptance of Nature’s law. In order to win the hand of a beautiful woman, Sayo, he must impress her father, a teacher in jujitsu. The finest master of jujitsu, the implacable Higaki, also seeks the hand of Sayo and vows to kill Sanshiro in a midnight fight on a windswept mountainside. Made during World War II, ‘Judo Saga’ lacked the propagandist angle found in many Japanese films of that era, and the film was heavily censored with 1,856 feet of film removed. A tale of romance, and martial arts, Kurosawa’s first feature is a strikingly visual film extraordinary for its explosive martial arts choreography.

Credits: Producer, Keiji Matsuzaki ; director, writer, Akira Kurosawa ; photography, Akira Mimura ; music, Seichi Suzuki ; editing, Toshio Goto, Akira Kurosawa.
Cast: Denjiro Okochi, Susumu Fujita, Yukiko Todoroki, Ryunosuke Tsukigata, Takashi Shimura, Ranko Hanai.

A leisurely stroll through Dublin with John Huston, examining the uprising of 1916 through the plight of Ireland today.

results.title: Sugar Town
results.creator_credit: Kurt Voss, Allison Anders, Daniel Hassid and Sugartown Productions
results.brief_description: The California music scene is evocatively captured in Alison Anders second collaboration with Kurt Voss (they worked together on a film about punk music in LA), using real life musicians Martin Kemp, John Taylor and John Doe. Gwen (Jade Gordon) is a PA to Liz (Ally Sheedy), the slightly neurotic production designer. Gwen is a calculating career woman and aspiring singer, recently fired from Liz’s actress friend, Eva (Patricia Arquette), who caught Gwen stealing her contraception in an effort to get “closer” to her husband, Clive (John Taylor), an ex rocker. Clive is part of a group of three ageing Brit rockers - Nick, Clive and Jonesy, disgruntled to find they cannot cut another record deal unless Nick (Michael Des Barres), agrees to sleep with potential investor Jane (Beverly D’Angelo). Add to this mix an illegitimate son, infidelity, a pregnancy and coveting your brothers wife, yet somehow the elements hang together through the characters varying relationship to rock music. Written by Allison Anders and Kurt Voss.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kurt Voss, Allison Anders, Daniel Hassid and Sugartown Productions

results.title: Hildegard Knef's Berlin
results.creator_credit: John McGreevy, Pat Ferns, Nielsen-Ferns International and John McGreevy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cities”.
Hildegard Knef opens Berlin to the viewers of this film in an extensively historical yet highly personal manner. She introduces us to her personal family history and to the ramifications of Nazi power. The tour also includes historical footage of the “formidable women who cleaned up the rubble of demolished Berlin” after World War II, of John Kennedy’s famous speech declaring his Berlin citizenship, of the 15-foot-high concrete barricade that divides the city, and of the airlift that kept the city of two million people totally supplied.

results.title: Studs Terkel's Chicago
results.creator_credit: John McGreevy, Pat Ferns, Nielsen-Ferns International and John McGreevy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cities”.
Studs Terkel, a resident of Chicago since his childhood, proudly displays the city and its ‘ethnic parade’. The ‘parade’ takes us on a view of Picasso’s statue, of Louis Sullivan’s skyscrapers, on a ride on the ‘El’ and a visit to the ‘Loop’. Terkel also takes us to the Chicago River, the Art Institute, Lincoln Park, Maxwell Street and finally, into the ethnic areas decorated by proud people.

results.title: Peter Ustinov's Leningrad
results.creator_credit: John McGreevy, Pat Ferns, Nielsen-Ferns and John McGreevy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cities”.
Presents Peter Ustinov’s personal view of Leningrad. He briefly relates the city’s history, showing many of the buildings - St. Peter and St. Paul Cathedral, the Imperial Winter Palace, St. Isaac’s Cathedral, amongst many others. He discusses many aspects of the arts, literature, music ballet and drama of Leningrad.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John McGreevy, Pat Ferns, Nielsen-Ferns and John McGreevy Productions
